The difference is that Romney's sole goal was to make money for himself, his partners, and his investors. If that meant eliminating the jobs of employees of his portfolio companies, he'd do that with equanimity, but if hiring was required he'd try to create the fewest jobs at the lowest pay and minimal benefits. And if a Bain portfolio company was so successful it added high-paid jobs but put its competitor out of business with the net result being a net loss of jobs, that would be just fine with Bain. That's not criticism, it's just the nature of being a self-interested financial-driven capitalist.

In contrast though, a president is required to create conditions and incentives that foster a national increase in jobs at higher wages in order to create economic prosperity. Supporting new technology companies is one good way of doing that, and opposing the replacement of high-paying jobs in Seattle with lower-wage jobs in South Carolina is another. Short-term job creation at any cost to the environment or to public health is not the goal, particularly when a re-routing of a pipeline would create just as many jobs with less damage.

Just because someone has done quite well for himself doesn't mean he knows anything at all about how to create the greatest good for the greatest number.

Kevin Phillips takes a long term look at inequality in "Wealth and Democracy." He points out that there is a feedback in economic distribution because as the rich get richer, they use their wealth to get more power--military a long time ago, political today. They then use their power to get more wealth and so on. There seems to be a tipping point where this process becomes impossible to reverse. When inequality becomes bad enough, the country soon goes down the tubes. He gives several examples.

According to Phillips, the great success of America has been that before the tipping point was reached, something has always happened that reverse the flow of money upwards, e.g. the rise of unions, FDR's reforms.

have we gone beyond the tipping point? Has ineauality be irreversible?

We should realize that those we are dealing with are sociopaths and will take the bargaining to the end result of war...maybe not with lethal weapons but cunning, guile, deceit, discrimination, indebtedness, and poverty are obviously being used today. Economics is about allocation of resources. And the sociopaths intend take it all.

Unfortunately, it seems, that the concentration of wealth is now so pervasive that it controls and distorts the information through corporate media so that a large portion of the electorate doesn't really know what is going on and, in fact, vote against issues and politicians that would actually benefit them.

George Orwell described this as Newspeak.

Also, It's very sad that our education system has enabled the citizens of this former democracy to allow that concentrated wealth to basically tell them that up is down and right is wrong.

Romney says that Obama believes that “government should create equal outcomes”

Mr. Romney obviously has inputs and outcomes all mixed up.

There is only one governing principle in American society today: Free Contract. In such a society bargaining power IS everything. What you make or earn, is a function of your bargaining power. If you've ever had it, you know it.

Whether its personal grooming, advertising on TV, or the antics taking place in Washington & Wall Street, everything that goes on around us has to do with individuals or groups trying to obtain greater bargaining power.

Consider: since 1972, the GNP has gone up on the order of 150%, while the median wage has remained flat. All the gains have gone to the rich.

Why? Bargaining power.

You'll note bargaining power isn't an outcome for determining wealth, or its distribution, IT'S AN INPUT! (STUPID!)

The problem with concentrated wealth, aside from the widespread suffering it causes our fellow citizens, is that it is a destroyer of Civilizations, Nations and Societies.

The founders were well aware of this. To compensate they gave us democracy, a form of political socialism (one man, one vote) with the idea that the masses would use their political power to level the playing field upon which bargaining takes place.

I can't speak for Obama, but Progressives don't believe in equal outcomes, just equal inputs. Then, let the chips fall where they will. Not everyone will choose money.

The Republican candidates running for their party's nomination like to ignore the history of their party and its Presidents, or worse, rewrite and distort that history.
The most recent "debate" in New Hampshire was full of statements that would not get by fact checking, gave false numbers, and blamed Obama for all of the Bush-Cheney initiated problems.
In wishing to cut regulations, they ignore that failure to regulate caused the financial crisis in 2007-8. They ignore that every company that can benefits from corporate welfare and tax loopholes. They almost to a man ignore the disaster of the Iraq war and its cost in men and treasure. They also ignore, like most of the press, that Iraq was the primary check on the ambitions of Iran. Saddam Hussein was an unpleasant dictator, but he made sure that Iran did not get very powerful.
Most deplorable is that too many American votes tend to swallow the distorted information and the slogans that come from almost all candidates. Voter gullibility and allowing religion to enter the political discourse will be our downfall.
"Remember the Alamo" was a slogan that caught on. What we need now is a slogan for the multiple problems that "43" hoisted on the nation.

I think what is being ignored is the saddest aspect of this campaign. With Michelle Bachmann out, every candidate left is an old, rich, white guy. If you leaf through history, all of our Presidents were rich, white guys, most of them old when they took office. Obama is neither that old nor white as those guys, and these candidates, and the only reason Bush is being mentioned is because "old, white, rich guy" connotes power in our culture, and it connotes "competent powerful figure" to the conservative, reactionary voters who would go for someone like Santorum. Bush is only now being mentioned because we've had three years of bleating and shouting that Obama is "the other," he's a Muslim, he's a secret terrorist, he's not really an American and isn't legitimately President, he's a liar, he wants to kill people by withholding health care, etc.

The conservative media have repeated this so often that the voters who haven't yet abandoned the Republican party believe these racist lies, so now it's safe to bring up Bush because he certainly couldn't be that bad. There's nothing to sell voters on except nostalgia for the lily white halls of power, and that's what they're going with.

This is really an issue of psychology. The basis of all political propaganda are myths - on the left and on the right. They do not deal with reality but fantasies. There is a problem with that: people remember events that took place short time ago better than the more distant in time.

There is always the danger that people, subconsciously, will do a reality check. After some 20 years it is not easy. Myths are easily accepted as facts. Not so for events just 5 years ago.

As far as I remember, Obama did not dwell much on Clinton's positives and negatives. Well, he also had another Clinton to deal with and she used to be considered a sure bet at first.

Anyway, these are the facts as I see it. Another myth cloaked in a pseudopsychological babble? Possible, I have a PhD in chemistry, not a 'talking and feeling' science.

And why has the GOP turned their back on Herbert Hoover? I believe that Saint Reagan is lionized because he was the last semi-likeable Republican President since Eisenhower. Reagan with all his faults seemed human and friendly though his kids tell us he was a cold as ice father. But grouped with Nixon & the Bushes, Reagan really stands out and therefore is the only past R president that can be mentioned in positive terms.....if you don't dig too deeply into his 8 years in office, of course.

Let's review the last 112 years....the GOP can only boast about Teddy Roosevelt, Eisenhower, and Reagan. That's pretty slim pickings in such a span of history. And someday we'll learn the awful truth about George W. Bush and we'll better understand why he hides like a rat...like the rat he truly is.

What a horrible way to start a day when you wake up knowing you have to spend the day pretending there are good things to say about Romney, Newt, Perry, Santorum, Ron Paul....how depressing. And how sad that half our population actually consider any of these stooges/crooks for the presidency. It's hard enough for me to espouse my support for the Democratic Corporatist in this race, but thank Allah I don't have to pretend Obama is sane, he's sane alright, but like the others he's under corporate ownership too.

Too bad Occupy isn't fielding a candidate this year.

Do you know of one sector that believes this president and this Congress are succeeding in turning the economy around? Yet all they like to do is remind folks of the Bush administration. As they say in the country, that was then this is now and what have you done for us lately? As someone whose 55 year old husband has been jobless and also without any sort of income because he was a sales rep, I find no reason to support Obama or any other self serving Democrat.
